ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Polar properties of hydrothermally synthesized BiFeO3 thin films

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Chemical Science and Technology and NAST Center

OrgAddress.Street: Tor Vergata Via della Ricerca Scientifica 1

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Multiferroic bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) has attracted considerable attention due to applications related to the bulk photovoltaic effect in which the direction of polarization determines the direction of the photocurrent. Epitaxial thin films are produced by means of techniques that usually require high temperature processes. The hydrothermal method can be seen as an alternative route to obtain highly textured thin films in quantities compatible with batch processing; nevertheless, the structural, dielectric and electric properties are generally affected by the presence of hydrogen and other reaction by-products. In this work, functional and highly textured BiFeO3 films were successfully produced on metallic SrTiO3:Nb (0.5 wt.%) (100) substrates via hydrothermal synthesis. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) were used to analyze the structural properties of the films. Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (PFM) and Photoconductive Atomic Force Microscopy (Pc-AFM) were used to determine their functional properties. We show the polarization switching and confirm the presence of the bulk photovoltaic effect for the first time in hydrothermally synthesized BiFeO3.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Facing an increasing demand for alternative and renewable energy sources, researchers have begun to screen a broader spectrum of photovoltaic materials. Complex oxide compounds can be inexpensive and stable, and their properties can be tuned in order to be applied for photovoltaic applications [1]. The low mobility of charge carriers and the large band gap have so far impeded the use of bulk photovoltaic materials in solar cells and their use might indeed be in optoelectronic sensor applications instead. In conventional semiconductor-based solar cells, electron–hole pairs are created at a pn-junction. The electrons increase the minority carrier density in the p-type region and the holes in the n-type region. The minority excess lowers the potential at the junction, which might be compensated by a current to the electrodes [1, 2]. In contrast to p-n junctions, polar materials such as ferroelectrics, exhibit an intrinsic electric field due to their crystal structure. This field can give rise to a charge separation of photo-excited electron–hole pairs. When these charges reach external electrodes, an electrical current is generated. This phenomenon is known as the bulk photovoltaic effect (BPVE) [2, 3], governed by a third-rank tensor. The main characteristics of this effect are its large, non-equilibrium photovoltage and its small photocurrent, which is oriented according to the polarization direction and charge-carrier separation in homogeneous media [2, 3].

Bismuth ferrite is a multiferroic material with polar and magnetic ordering coexisting at room temperature [4, 5]. It has a rhombohedral perovskite structure in bulk (monoclinic in thin films) with bismuth atoms located at the corners of the cell, iron at the center, and oxygen at the face centers [4]. It has excellent ferroelectric and piezoelectric properties and it is considered to be a suitable material for high-temperature applications because of its ferroelectric Curie temperature (T c)∼830 ∘C and Néel temperature (T N) ∼370 ∘C [6]. Its relatively small band gap of ∼2.74 eV makes it an interesting candidate for high performance photovoltaic and optoelectronic applications [2]. Memory devices based on its magnetoelectric effect are another possible application. Photovoltaics require highly oriented films. For that purpose, epitaxial films of BiFeO3 have been produced by RF-sputtering [2], chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [3, 7], or pulsed laser deposition (PLD) [6, 8] showing a photovoltaic effect.

Hydrothermal synthesis is an easily extendable and inexpensive technique and we present its suitability for growing highly oriented films. The process can be defined as any reaction in presence of aqueous solvents above room temperature and autogenous pressure greater than 1 bar due to water vapor pressure in a closed system [9]; in this case, with a Teflon (PTFE) liner inside a stainless steel autoclave. Ferroelectric perovskite films synthesize by island nucleation and growth. When the islands reach sufficient size, coalescence follows and a new layer is formed on the first one [10, 11]. The size of nanocrystals depends mostly on processing temperature and time. In a controlled nucleation process, uniform nanocrystals can be grown [12]. This technique was already used to synthesize BiFeO3 epitaxial films [13, 14], but so far its successful application in electronics has not been reported due to high electric leakage [13]. With BiFeO3 being a wide-band-gap semiconductor, leakage originates from dopants that are introduced through the solvent (hydrogen from water in our case), other reaction educts (catalysts, surfactants and mineralizers), and reaction by-products. In order to reduce leakage, we annealed the sample to remove hydrogen; we abstained from surfactants and, most importantly, significantly reduced the concentration of potassium hydroxide (KOH) by a factor of 10 compared to reports in literature [13]. As mineralizer, KOH promotes solubility of reactants and considerably accelerates crystal growth; nevertheless, potassium is in a 1+ state while all cations of BiFeO3 are in a 3+ state. Potassium thus represents an aliovalent substitution that will induce substantial leakage acting as a dopant [15]. Another reason for reducing the KOH concentration is that potassium nitrate (KNO3) might be produced in a secondary reaction with the nitrite coming from the precursors. KNO3 is known to be a room temperature ferroelectric on its own [16].

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The film synthesis was carried out using Bi(NO3)3∗5H2O granules (Sigma-Aldrich >99.99 %) and Fe(NO3)3∗9H2O granules (Sigma-Aldrich >98 %) as precursors at an equimolar concentration Bi:Fe of 0.3 M; also, 0.75 M of KOH (Sigma-Aldrich >99.995 %) was added as mineralizer. A previously treated SrTiO3:Nb (0.5 wt.%) (100) single crystal substrate (miscut angle <0.3∘, step height of 0.4 nm, single termination) was put into a PTFE holder and laid facing downwards in a PTFE liner 1 cm above the bottom in order to promote convection as the primary material transport mechanism for thin film growth. Reaction, nucleation, crystallization and film growth were then carried out in a general purpose reactor (Parr mod 4749) at a temperature of 200 ∘C with a volume fill factor of 66 % during 18 h in a Carbolite oven (model PN 30). The as-grown films were annealed for 5 minutes at 500 ∘C under nitrogen flow for better crystallization and to remove hydrogen from the sample.

The topography, piezoresponse and local photocurrent were measured by Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (PFM) and Photoconductive-AFM (Pc-AFM), respectively (Smart SPM1000 from AIST-NT, Inc.). The structural properties were analyzed by XRD (Panalytical Xpert Pro) using theta-2theta mode. The crystallite size was calculated using the Scherrer equation and the out-of-plane lattice parameter was determined using the Nelson Riley extrapolation function [17]. The film thickness was estimated by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) (Jeol JSM-6300F) on the cross-sectional area. Pc-AFM was conducted by illuminating the sample locally with a UV laser (355 nm wavelength, 3 mW power, 0.4 NA objective) in order to confirm the presence of a bulk photovoltaic effect.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
An SEM cross section and top view of the synthesized BiFeO3 film are shown in Fig. 1. The low concentration of the mineralizer KOH leads to less solubility of the precursors and decreases the reaction rate; 18 h were required to grow 40-nm thin films.
Fig. 1
SEM images of the BiFeO3 film. (a) Cross section showing the substrate and the 40-nm thin film. (b) Top view showing the edge of the substrate that is covered by BiFeO3

The AFM topography is shown in Fig. 2. The square shaped islands of up to 60 nm in height are attributed to an epitaxial growth of BiFeO3 on SrTiO3, which has a cubic cell structure.
Fig. 2
AFM topography image. A fourfold symmetry is clearly visible indicating an ordered growth along the crystallographic axes of the substrate

The bismuth ferrite phase is verified in a high resolution semi-logarithmic theta-2theta diffractogram represented in Fig. 3. The XRD scan was acquired with a (440) Ge monochromator in order to avoid secondary radiations from tungsten contamination (L
α ) and secondary copper (K
α2, K
β ) lines from source and cathode, respectively. The calculated out-of-plane lattice parameter is 4.16 Å and in good agreement with literature [18]. The crystallite size derived from the Scherrer equation is 37 nm. No traces of KNO3 were found by additional XRD measurements.
Fig. 3
Semi-logarithmic theta–2theta plot showing the BiFeO3 phase in (200) plane

In the present work, ferroelectric switching is shown for the first time in hydrothermally synthesized BiFeO3 thin films. Figure 4(a) shows a PFM phase-contrast image depicting an intentionally written ferroelectric pattern where some areas are poled “upwards” and some “downwards”. Using an AFM tip with a conductive coating and by applying an electrical bias potential, we poled three intersecting squares located from the top left to the bottom right with voltages of −8, 6 and −8 V, respectively. The remaining area corresponds to the virgin state which exhibits a preferential upwards-orientation. The intersecting squares are showing the capability of the material to go through a full cycle of ferroelectric polarization switching. This is also confirmed in Fig. 4(b) by a ferroelectric hysteresis loop between −10 and 10 V where a phase shift of 180∘ out-of-plane is shown.
Fig. 4
(a) PFM phase contrast image. (b) Local phase hysteresis showing 180∘ switching

The bulk photovoltaic effect is shown in Fig. 5, where the image (a) corresponds to the topography in contact mode, and the image (b) to the short-circuit photocurrent response generated by the incident light.
Fig. 5
(a) AFM contact mode topography and (b) simultaneously measured photocurrent in short-circuit configuration under 355-nm excitation

The topography scans in Fig. 2 and Fig. 5(a) show that the sample surface is not homogeneously covered by the BiFeO3 film. Although we assume that the substrate is homogeneously heated during growth, we do not control the direction of the convectional flow, which will most likely be turbulent in a small vessel. Figures 2 and 5 were obtained on different areas of the same sample.

Due to the low concentration of the mineralizer KOH, up to 18 h were required to grow 40-nm thin films. This clearly represents a roadblock for industrial batch processing but recent experiments from our group with microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of BiFeO3 nanoplates have shown the potential to decrease the reaction time to a few minutes [19]. Experiments to apply this technique to thin films are currently on the way.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Highly ordered BiFeO3 thin films were successfully produced by hydrothermal synthesis on SrTiO3:Nb (100) substrates. For the first time, polarization reversal is demonstrated by successful reduction of electric leakage. A first demonstration of the bulk photovoltaic effect in hydrothermally grown BiFeO3 shows that this technique can be used to produce multiferroics for photovoltaic applications.
